1.0    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.1    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Rayonier Performance Fibers (RPF), LLC Fernandina Plant is committed to the safety of workers and the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  RPF implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  These controls include training programs for personnel; programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes; and programs to evaluate possible hazards.



In the event of an accidental release, RPF implements policies and procedures to protect employees and prevent injury to the public and the environment.  RayAM provides "First Responder" training to responsible personnel, designates an emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities, and coordinates response efforts with the Nassau County Emergency Management team and the local fire department.







1.2

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



Rayonier Performance Fibers, LLC Fernandina Plant, located in Fernandina Beach, Florida, is an ammonia-base dissolving sulfite pulp mill, which produces approximately 150,000 tons of highly purified specialty pulp annually.  To manufacture these quality pulps to specific customer specifications, RPF uses four chemicals subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP). The RPF Fernandina Plant is classified as NAICS Code 32211 and is consequently subject to the Program Level 3 requirements of RMP.  These same four substances are also subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations and are listed below:  

1. Ammonia (anhydrous)

2. Chlorine

3. Chlorine dioxide

4. Sulfur dioxide (anhydrous)

Ammonia and sulfur dioxide are used to make up cooking acid for pulps.  Chlorine and chlorine dioxide are used as bleaching chemicals in the process. 

The maximum ammonia inventory onsite decreased due to switching from railcars to bulk trucks.  The maximum chlorine inventory onsite decreased due to the reduction from 4 to 2 chlorine railcars.  The maximum sulfur dioxide inventory onsite increased changing from approximately 4 to 6 sulfur dioxide railcars.  The maximum chlorine dioxide inventory onsite did not change and includes the two chlorine dioxide storage tanks with concentrations above the 1.0% minimum level specified in the RMP regulation.

1.4   PREVENTION PROGRAM - PROGRAM 3



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant is subject to both EPA and OSHA process safety management regulations. The plant focus is on the development and implementation of effective management systems to address the hazards of our processes and to meet the spirit and intent of the applicable regulations. Additionally, the plant identifies and addresses opportunities to further improve safety performance at the plant through comprehensive internal and third pa

rty audits aimed at process safety program elements. The following 12 sections provide a brief description of the plant's management systems to address the program 3 accident prevention provisions of the EPA's RMP regulation.



1.4.1   Process Safety Information



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant has compiled written Process Safety Information (PSI) before conducting any process hazard analysis as required by the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The PSM standard requirements for PSI are identical to those required by the RMP in 40 CFR 68.65.  This compilation of written process safety information enables RPF and the employees involved in operating the processes to identify and understand the possible hazards posed by those processes involving toxic substances.  PSI includes information pertaining to the hazards of the toxic substances used in the process, information pertaining to the technology of the process, and information pertaining to the equipment in the process.



PSI has been collected and updated for RPF's four RMP process systems: ammonia (anhydrous), chlorine, chlorine dioxide, and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous). Safety Data Sheets (SDS), block flow diagrams, piping and instrumentation diagrams (P & IDs), and equipment information are stored in the PSM Information books, drawings, and equipment files.



1.4.2    Process Hazard Review



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant has performed an initial Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) on all four covered processes as well as periodic analyses as required by the PSM/RMP regulations.  The PSM standard requirements for PHAs are identical to those required by the RMP in 40 CFR 68.67.  Initial PHAs were completed by May 1997 for RayAM's four PSM/RMP process systems:  ammonia (anhydrous), chlorine, chlorine dioxide, and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous).  Revalidations are required at least every five years and the current frequency of the process hazard reviews for all processes meets t

hat five year requirement.    

Of the methods commonly used for analysis or reviews, the "HAZOP" and "Checklist" methods are typically used at the Fernandina plant.  PHA's identify, evaluate and control hazards involved in the process.  RPF also has a system in place to address findings and recommendations that result from these studies.





1.4.3    Operating Procedures



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant has developed, implemented, and maintains clearly written detailed procedures for safely operating and maintaining a process during all operating modes.  In addition to operating procedures, safe work practices have been developed and implemented for the control of hazards and include hot work, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, lockout/tagout, and control over the entrance into a stationary source.  These safe work procedures are in place and are reviewed and revised as needed, but at least on an annual basis.





1.4.4    Training



Each employee at Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant involved in operating a covered process has been trained to operate it safely and understands the training.  They also have been trained in the safety and health hazards of each process as required by 40 CFR 68.71 and evaluated for understanding of the training by a written test and/or on the job observations.



Refresher training is provided every three years or more often if necessary.  RPF also gathers input from the employees involved in operating covered processes to aid in determining the appropriate frequency of refresher training.  This input is accomplished by the use of a refresher training frequency survey. 





1.4.5    Mechanical Integrity



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant already has a mechanical integrity system in place due to the requirements of PSM.  Under the RMP rule 40 CFR 68.73, RPF has adopted this mechanical integrity system.  The system ensures that the process equipment and instru

mentation are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases.  It includes written procedures, training, inspection, and testing, correcting system deficiencies and quality assurance.  These tasks are discussed further in the PSM Mechanical Integrity manual.





1.4.6    Management of Change



A Management of Change (MOC) system is in place at Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant to prevent changes in the process and supporting equipment from introducing unacceptable hazards to workers.  This MOC system has written procedures for managing changes to be made to a PSM/RMP covered process.  The procedures require review prior to the change with a special emphasis on safety and training of employees and contractors.  Process Safety Information (PSI) and procedures are updated when a change is made. 





1.4.7    Pre-Startup Review



Prior to starting up any new covered process or modified covered process, Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant performs a pre-startup safety review when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.  This review ensures all requirements are met before the introduction of any highly hazardous chemical into a new or modified process.  This review is done before startup to verify that safety issues have been addressed. This final pre-startup review aids in ensuring that changes in the system are properly installed and tested before startup.  





1.4.8    Compliance Audits



At least every three years, Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant evaluates the effectiveness of the PSM/RMP system.  Audits are performed to determine that the system complies with the provisions in the PSM/RMP standard and that the systems procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed.  PSM/RMP audits are retained until all action items are completed and two subsequent audits are performed.  RPF's most recent compliance audit

for PSM/RMP was performed in June, 2018. An external compliance audit by an agency is scheduled to be conducted in October, 2018 by the State of Florida Division of Emergency Management.  





1.4.9    Incident Investigation



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant investigates every incident, which results in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  The investigation starts as soon as possible but not later than 48 hours after an incident.  The incident investigation system identifies factors that contributed to the incident and records recommendations resulting from the investigation. The plant has an established system to address the recommendations and findings and records their resolution. Incident reports are retained for at least five years.





1.4.10    Employee Participation



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant has developed a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation in evaluating covered processes.  RPF consults with and involves employees and their representatives to obtain feedback on PSM related programs and actions for covered processes.  This written employee participation plan is located in the plant's PSM/RMP documentation.  Employees participate in the development of PSM programs and in their implementation including PHAs, gathering information, incident investigations, training, written operating procedures, and the other PSM/RMP program elements as required.





1.4.11    Hot Work Permit



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant issues hot work permits for any hot work operations conducted on or near covered processes.  Each permit documents that the fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252 (a) have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations.  They also indicate the date(s) and time authorized for hot work and the identity of the object on which hot work is to be performed.  After the h

each facility.  RMP defines accidental releases from covered process as those that resulted in (1) on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage, or (2) known off-site consequences such as death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



A review of the five-year accident history at RPF identifed two OSHA recordable incidents from PSM covered processes which occurred on June 21, 2017 and February 6, 2015.  For the June 21, 2017 incident, four onsite OSHA recordable injuries occurred.  There were no offsite consequences.  An internal incident investigation was initiated on June 21, 2017.  A root cause analysis was performed and corrective action items were identified.  For the February 6, 2015 incident, one onsite OSHA recordable injury occurred.  There were no offsite consequences.  A root cause analysis was performed and corrective action items were identified and completed.  Section 6 Five Year Accident History online report was revised to include specific details of both incidents.





1.6   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant has a written emergency response plan for the Fernandina facility to aid in safely responding to accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  This emergency response plan includes procedures for:



1.  Training responsible employees on procedures for being the "First Responder" in the event of a release.

2.  Providing proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat accidental human exposure to hazardous substances.

3.  Controlling and containing accidental releases of hazardous substances, including the use of emergency response equipment.

4.  Informing the local Nassau County Emergency Management team, which is responsible for responding to accidental releases, which could reasonably result in off site consequences. 

5.  Procedures for informing the public when necessary. 

6.  Inspecting and maintaining emergency response equ

ipment.

7.  Reviewing and updating the emergency response plan.



RPF maintains an emergency response team trained in these emergency response procedures.  All plant personnel are trained in evacuation procedures.  RPF periodically conducts emergency response drills.  The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations [i.e. OSHA regulations 29 CFR 1910.38(a) and 29 CFR 1910.120(a)] and has been communicated to the local emergency response officials.  RPF also maintains a regular dialogue with the local fire chief and routinely provides required information.





1.7   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Rayonier Performance Fibers LLC Fernandina Plant continuously strives to improve safety. There are multiple systems in place to achieve this goal. The plant focuses on proactive safety actions, including a safety observation and near miss reporting program, See Something, Say Something. The observation program is based on influencing behavior by conducting observations and providing feedback to both employees and contractors as they perform their duties. The near miss reporting program is focused on addressing employee concerns and issues before an incident occurs.



Other efforts to improve safety include the development and use of JSAs and SOPs. These programs focus on systematically analyzing jobs to address the hazards and risks. Employees participate in these programs by providing input on each analysis. The resulting JSAs and SOPs are used in training employees how to safely do their jobs. 



Incident investigations are also performed to improve safety. These investigations are conducted when an incident occurs, using TapRoot and 5 Why methodologies. Corrective actions are tracked to closure. Lessons learned are communicated to prevent recurrence.



Recent process safety improvements planned or completed include the following: 



With the upgrade of the chlorine dioxide generator, additional fixed stationary moni

tors have been added. In addition to the fixed monitors, the Plant wide monitoring program has added expanded monitoring capabilities with real-time data readily available.   



The number of chlorine railcars onsite has been reduced due to less demand for chlorine use at the plant which reduces the maximum chlorine contained onsite.



The unloading operations for the Ammonia system have been relocated away from high traffic areas.  This change will minimize potential exposure in the event of a failure or releases during the unloading operations. Ammonia bulk trucks will be used instead of rail cars for delivery reducing the maximum ammonia contained onsite.  Emergency shut-off smart hoses are used with the ammonia bulk trucks to shut off flow if sensors indicate to do so.  Cameras have been added at the ammonia truck unloading stations.
